Speaker.hpid: Mr. V. Brady Mr. V. Brady
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the action which has been taken by him to implement the many important recommendations for legislative change in the Ombudsman report 1984.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The annual report of the Ombudsman 1984 suggested that legislation be reviewed in relation to the following matters affecting the Department of Social Welfare: (i) qualification for old age contributory pension; (ii) the deserted husband; (iii) trade disputes; (iv) entitlements based on the law of domicile; (v) the question of interest on delayed payments under the Social Welfare Acts.

The problems regarding old age contributory pension and the deserted husband are being examined by the Commission on Social Welfare and the position will be reviewed in the light of the commission's recommendations.

The legal provisions regarding trade disputes are being examined. Discussions with the trade unions and employers' representative bodies will be necessary and any changes which are agreed will be implemented as soon as possible.

The law on domicile can affect claims for widows' pensions under the Social Welfare Acts. As indicated in the Ombudsman report, the Law Reform Commission has put forward recommendations for change in regard to the question of domicile, and the question of implementing the recommendations of that commission is currently being examined by the Minister for Justice.

Having regard to available staff resources every effort is made to minimise delays in social welfare payments. There is no provision in existing law for the payment of interest in such circumstances, many of which are outside the control of the Department. In the present state of the public finances the introduction of interest payments is not regarded as a priority item.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: To qualify for a free electricity allowance, a person must reside alone or with categories of persons whose residence is excepted for the purposes of the scheme. Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The allocation of £1 million for the anti-poverty programme in 1985 was for the establishment of a Combat Poverty Agency and to fund the agency's activities this year. Legislation to establish the agency, having passed all stages in Seanad Éireann will now be discussed in the Dáil and the agency will be established as soon as possible after the legislation has been enacted. Pending the establishment of the agency funds have not been granted to any organisation from this allocation.

A limited amount of expenditure from this allocation has arisen in connection with the preparations for the EC poverty programme. Under this programme eight projects from this country have been selected and they will commence shortly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: One of the conditions for the receipt of a deserted wife's payment is that a person's husband must have left her on his own volition. The claim of the person concerned to a deserted wife's payment was disallowed because the deciding officer held that this condition was not satisfied in her case.

The claimant appealed against the decision and an oral hearing of her case was held on 8 August 1985. Based on the available evidence, the appeals officer considered that the separation was caused by a mutual breakdown of the marriage and he accordingly upheld the decision of the deciding officer.

The appeals officer's decision is final and conclusive and can only be reviewed in the light of new facts or fresh evidence being made available to him since the appeal hearing. Should the person concerned wish to make any further statement or submit any other evidence she should forward it and it will be referred to the appeals officer for consideration.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare whether his Department gave instructions to social welfare officers to either disqualify farmers' sons or else to reduce substantially their rate of unemployment assistance, in cases where they are living in homes outside of the farm and outside of the family home and in some cases where such applicants are married and where they have no visible means of income or support; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The items which constitute means for unemployment assistance purposes are set out in section 146 of the Social Welfare (Consolidation) Act, 1981, and in the Unemployment Assistance (Calculation of Means) Regulations 1934, as amended.

The means test for all unemployment assistance claimants is carried out in accordance with the legislation. There are detailed administrative arrangements designed to ensure that each claimant is treated equitably. No instructions on the lines suggested have been issued by the Department. If the Deputy is aware of any cases which he feels warrant reinvestigation he should advise the Department of the details so that the cases can be examined without delay.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: A claimant for unemployment benefit who is a landholder but does not satisfy the contribution condition of having 78 paid contributions in either the last three complete contribution years immediately preceding the date of his claim or in the three years immediately preceding that date, is not entitled to unemployment benefit if the income from his holding exceeds £2 daily.

The person concerned who is a seasonal worker in Bord na Móna is also a landholder. He does not satisfy the contribution condition in the last three complete contribution years as he had only 76 contributions during this period. Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the number of Garda summonses struck out due to incorrect details appearing on the summons, for the last full year prior to the computerisation of summonses and also for the year ended 31 December 1984.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of the frustration among gardaí arising from the insertion of incorrect details on summonses over which they have no control, following computerisation and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is satisfied that the computerisation is carried out with maximum efficiency; and the action he proposes to take where incorrect details on summonses result in charges being struck out.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I propose to take Questions Nos. 225 to 227, inclusive, together. My Department has received no complaints along the lines suggested in these questions and I find it difficult to see how such complaints could arise.

As in all such systems some initial errors must arise in the issue of summonses by computer but, so far, the numbers concerned have been well within the level of tolerance normally applied to these systems in the judgment of persons qualified to assess such matters. But I must emphasise that these are only initial errors and that the system contains a built-in corrective for errors of this kind. When the garda who makes the complaint on which the summons is issued receives a copy of it, he is required under standing instructions to check it carefully and bring any error to notice immediately so that it may be corrected before the date of hearing. In the circumstances any error that persists to the date of hearing must be the responsibility of the gardaí concerned and I fail to see how gardaí could have a reasonable cause for complaint about the new system. Indeed, my information is that the Garda authorities are satisfied that the system has resulted in a substantial improvement in effectiveness and efficiency.

Statistics of cases struck out because of error are not available for periods either before or after computerisation, and they could not be assembled without an inordinate expenditure on staff time and resources.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education (a) the current position with regard to the proposed extension to Rathcoffey national school, County Kildare; and (b) the number of planning stages still to be undertaken prior to going to contract in relation to the said school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 233 and 234 together.

The chairman of the board of management of Rathcoffey national school, County Kildare, has been authorised to engage his own architect to undertake the planning of the proposed extension to the school. It will be necessary to brief the architect, when appointed, in connection with the preparation and submission of a sketch plan. The project must go through the following further stages before the question of inviting tenders can arise; approval of sketch scheme including costings, agreement on the local contribution and preparation of contract documents.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Coughlan Mr. Coughlan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the up-to-date position regarding the proposed extension for Fintra national school, Killybegs, County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department has approved a revised sketch scheme for a proposed extension for Fintra national school, Killybegs, County Donegal. When title to the site extension which will be required in this case has been declared by the Chief State Solicitor to be satisfactory, my Department will be in a position to sanction formally a grant for the project, and to arrange for the remaining stages of architectural planning to be undertaken.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bell Mr. Bell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when sanction will be given to the appointment of a contractor for the proposed extension to the CBS primary school, Sunday's Gate, Drogheda, in view of the substantial delay that has arisen in relation to this project.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Tenders for the proposed extension to the Christian Brothers' national school, Sunday's Gate, Drogheda are at present being examined in my Department. A decision will be conveyed to the school authorities at the earliest possible date on the question of placing a contract for the project.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hyland Mr. Hyland
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if in view of the decision of Laois Vocational Education Committee to grant senior cycle status to Clonaslee vocational school, she will grant early approval on the basis of the submission made by the teachers and parents of the area serviced by the school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: An application has been received from the County Laois Vocational Education Committee for sanction to operate a leaving certificate course at Clonaslee vocational school. I have agreed to meet a deputation from the committee to discuss the matter. When a decision has been reached it will be communicated to the committee and I shall arrange to have a copy sent to the Deputy for his information.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when construction will commence on an extension to a post primary school (details supplied) in County Wicklow.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department officially sanctioned acceptance of tenders for the extension referred to by the Deputy in a letter to the school authorities dated 25 October 1985, and the school authorities are in a position to authorise commencement of building. The school authorities are the clients in this case and it is understood that they await completion of certain necessary formalities by the building contractor in order to clear the way for signing a contract and commencement of construction.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Durkan Mr. Durkan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the plans she has for the improvement and extension of facilities at Ardclough national school in County Kildare; and when it is proposed to have the necessary work put in hand and the further planning and processing which is required before work can begin on the project.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department has agreed to grant-aid the provision of permanent accommodation comprising three classrooms, a general purposes area and ancillary accommodation at Ardclough national school, County Kildare. A sketch scheme submitted to my Department by the school authorities is being examined, and the outcome will be conveyed to them as soon as possible. The project must go through the following further stages of planning before the question of inviting tenders can arise: approval of sketch scheme, including projected costings, agreement on the local contribution and preparation of contract documents. It is not possible at this stage to say when building work may commence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Durkan Mr. Durkan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she is aware of the hardship caused to parents, teachers and children attending the number two national school, Monasterevin, County Kildare, due to the very poor conditions of the school; if she will take the necessary steps to have required improvements carried out before Christmas; if she has any plans to replace the existing facilities; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department has under consideration various proposals for the replacement of the classroom at present in use at No. 2 national school, Monasterevin, County Kildare. Capital expenditure on improvements to the existing structure has not been recommended by my Department's professional advisers. A decision in the matter will be conveyed in the near future to the school authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will provide the necessary facilities in one of the schools in the Clondalkin area for those students psychologically assessed as requiring special education; and if she would agree that adequate facilities are not available for such children.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: An application for the provision of a special class for pupils assessed as mildly mentally handicapped has been received from the schools serving the Neilstown, Rowlagh and Quarryvale areas of Clondalkin. My Department is at present considering how best to provide this facility in the light of the accommodation situation in the schools in question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Fitzgerald Mr. L. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if an unsuccessful applicant (details supplied) in Dublin 5 for a third-level grant in 1984 can now have her case reconsidered in the light of changed circumstances.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The higher education grants scheme, including the means test tables, applicable to the student in question is the scheme for 1984, that is, the scheme of the year in which she qualified academically for a grant by virtue of successes in the leaving certificate examination. Accordingly, the means test tables applicable to her are those in the scheme for 1984. Under these tables the income limit in order to qualify for a grant, with three dependent children in the family, is £10,400. As the reckonable income in this particular case exceeds that figure, the student does not qualify for a grant. The revised means test tables in the scheme for 1985 apply only to candidates who qualified academically for grants by virtue of successes in the leaving certificate examination, 1985. These 1985 tables do not apply retrospectively.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Begley Mr. Begley
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the up-to-date position regarding the building project at Castle-gregory national school, County Kerry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The preparation of contract documents for the proposed new national school at Castlegregory, County Kerry, is in hands and it is expected that they will be completed early in 1986. The question of inviting tenders for this project will then arise for consideration.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Ormonde Dr. Ormonde
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when a final payment will be made to the builder on completing the extension to Kilmacthomas vocational school, County Waterford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The question of the final payment to the builder of the extension is, in the first instance, a matter for County Waterford Vocational Education Committee. The final account for the project has been received in my Department and is currently under examination. It is expected that the examination will be completed in the near future and my Department will then be in contact with the vocational education committee.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Enright Mr. Enright
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the present position in regard to the provision of an extension to a school (details supplied) in County Offaly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department's professional advisers are at present preparing sketch plans for the proposed extension scheme for the County Offaly school referred to. As soon as these plans are available they will be referred to the school authorities for their consideration and approval.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Enright Mr. Enright
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the present position in regard to an application for the provision of additional accommodation at a school (details supplied) in County Offaly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The school referred to by the Deputy has, at present, four teachers and a special additional assistant catering for a small group of hearing-impaired children. Four classrooms and a general purposes area will be available as soon as a contract for the extension of the building has been completed. The question of additional teaching accommodation for ordinary school purposes will arise only if the enrolments are maintained at a level to warrant the employment and longer term retention of a fifth teacher. The question of accommodation to cater for the hearing-impaired children is being considered separately.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - School Leaving Age.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the number of children estimated to have left school before 15 years of age in each of the last five years; if the Government has any proposals to deal with the problem of children who leave school before the legal age; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy, in so far as it is available is as follows:
Estimates of outflow from full time education of pupils under 15 years of age.

MainHeading.P: * (It is not possible to distinguish leavers from first level by age. It has been assumed in the estimates given that all leavers from full time education in ordinary national schools are under 15 years of age.)

Data is not yet available in respect of leavers from the 1983-84 academic year. However, the report, on which the above estimates are in part based, of the 1985 school leavers survey (conducted annually by the Department of Labour) is due to be published shortly and in the circumstances I will write directly to the Deputy on the matter as soon as possible.

At present, in accordance with the provisions of the School Attendance Act, 1926, responsibility for enforcement of the Act in specified county boroughs and urban districts rests with school attendance committees and in all other areas the Garda Síochána are the enforcing authority.

In the Green Paper, Partners in Education, released on 11 November 1985 the provision of a general advisory and educational welfare service, which would include school attendance, is envisaged as a function of the proposed local education councils.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if a full maintenance grant will be paid to a person (details supplied) in Dublin 4 whose last remaining guardian died in April 1985 leaving him without support to complete his studies.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department is at present reconsidering the level of grant applicable to the student in question under the higher education grants scheme in the light of the case recently received from Dublin Corporation for the payment of the maintenance element of the grant in full. A decision will be conveyed to the corporation as quickly as possible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Aylward Mr. Aylward
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if any decision has yet been made on the application of a person (details supplied) in County Kilkenny for a higher education grant where the application was made through Kilkenny County Council.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: In the case in question it is understood from Kilkenny County Council's office that the reckonable income for the purposes of the means test in the higher education grants scheme for 1985 (i.e. the scheme of the year the student sat for the leaving certificate) is £12,693 and the number of dependent children in the family is three (3). On the basis of those figures the grant payable in accordance with the terms of the scheme is one quarter of the student's lecture fees.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cowen Mr. Cowen
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if full pension entitlements are to be paid to a retired school teacher (details supplied) in County Offaly on whose behalf Deputy Cowen has already made representations setting out her case in full.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The teacher concerned did not receive maximum pension benefits. The pension entitlements of national school teachers are based on the amount of pensionable service the individual teacher has on the date of retirement, the maximum benefits being based on 40 years' pensionable service.

As the teacher concerned had only five years and 330 days service which was reckonable as pensionable when she retired this year, her pension entitlements fell to be calculated on the basis of that amount of service only.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Donegal Sports Hall.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when it is proposed to erect a sports hall at Rosses community school, Dungloe, County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I have approved in principle the provision of a physical education hall at Rosses community school, Dungloe, County Donegal, with a view to construction commencing in 1986.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Appointment of Science Technician.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cowen Mr. Cowen
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the reason she is refusing to sanction the appointment of an extra science technician at Athlone regional technical college required there because of an additional course commenced in the college and sanctioned by the Department of Education; and if she will now confirm that that person is now being appointed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The question of the provision of additional technical support staff in Athlone RTC as in all other VEC colleges falls to be considered in the context of the Government's policy on the limitation of public service numbers. In this regard a request by County Westmeath VEC for authority to recruit additional technical support staff is under urgent examination. The creation of an additional post would be required before there could be any question of a person being appointed as requested by the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. V. Brady Mr. V. Brady
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the action which has taken by him to implement the many important recommendations for legislative change in the Ombudsman's report, 1984.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: There was no recommendation for legislative change in the Ombudsman's report, 1984, which required implementation by me.

Speaker.hpid: Mr Kirk Mr Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if a grant has been approved for Knockbridge Community Centre, County Louth; and, if so, when payment can be expected.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: A grant of £12,000 has been allocated to Knockbridge Parish Committee under the capital grant scheme for the construction of recreational facilities.
Payment of the grant will be make on receipt of certain documentation requested from the committee by my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Tallaght (Dublin) Youth Centre.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the up-to-date position concerning the application of BAADH Residents' Association, Tallaght, Dublin 24 for a grant under the capital grants scheme for their youth and recreation centre.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: A capital grant of £6,000 has been allocated to BAADH Residents' Association under the capital grants scheme for the construction of recreational facilities.

MainHeading.P: Payments will be made in instalments, as work progresses, based on 50 per cent the value of work shown on periodic architects' certificates which must be submitted to my Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the reason a person (details supplied) in County Wexford did not receive redundancy payment at the level which was certified by her former employer; and if arrangements will be made to pay her the full amount.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The statutory redundancy lump sum paid to the employee concerned was the equivalent of nine and a half week's gross wages, which amounted to £812.06. The amount of that lump sum was calculated by my Department in accordance with the provisions of the Redundancy Payments Acts, 1967 to 1984, based on the information supplied to the Department in respect of the employee's age, service with the firm and normal weekly pay.

The amount of lump sum claimed by the employee as calculated by the receiver of the company in which she had been employed was the equivalent of 10 weeks' pay but that calculation was incorrect. The receiver may in his calculation of the employee's reckonable service have omitted to take account of two periods of lay-off from 17 December 1984 to 4 January 1985 and from 25 February 1985 to 26 July 1985. Such periods are non-reckonable for the purposes of calculating a statutory redundancy lump sum.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he is aware that the Limerick youth service and the Southill community workshop are making deductions from the money of young people employed under the AnCO work experience programme for minor offences such as bad language and not wearing proper clothes; if he approves of such a policy; if he will take steps to ensure that any money so deducted will be returned to the young persons concerned; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: Community workshops are established and managed by community groups with financial assistance from AnCO and the Youth Employment Agency. AnCO monitors the quality of training provided and ensures that the funds provided are properly accounted for.

I have no function in the day to day running of community workshops which is a matter for the management committees. It would be inappropriate for me therefore to comment on the questions raised by the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he is aware of the demands of certain trade unions concerning the approvals and running of special employment schemes; if he is aware that approval for these schemes is only given by trade unions on the condition that the people employed become members of the trade union involved; that the organisers of these schemes have to act as recruitment officers for the said unions and that the contributions to the trade union has to be deducted by the organiseers of the scheme on a weekly basis at a sum set out by the union and forwarded to the union on special forms showing the names of the members and the amount deducted from each one; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: I take it that the Deputy is referring to the social employment scheme. In order to accelerate the processing of work projects under this scheme some project sponsors, particularly local authorities, have entered into negotiations with local branches of trade unions as a result of which agreements have been reached on matters such as staffing levels, supervision and union membership. Any such commitments have been entered into freely by the employing bodies. Since it is intended that the normal employer-employee relationships should prevail under the scheme it is not my intention to interfere in this process.

To ensure that all projects comply with the conditions of the scheme a monitoring committee comprised of representatives of the Department of Labour, Department of the Environment, AnCO and ICTU oversees the operation of the scheme on a national basis.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour when the social employment scheme will be approved for Rathmore-Barraduff-Killarney as recommended by Kerry County Council.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: An application under the social employment scheme by Kerry County Council in respect of the project referred to was originally submitted to the local National Manpower Service office at Killarney in April 1985.

At the request of the county council, the project was deferred, however, indefinitely so that priority could be given to other Kerry County Council sponsored projects which were considered more urgent.

The Manpower Service confirmed to the county council that it would postpone the processing of the application in favour of the council's subsequent, more urgent applications, and informed the council that should they wish to reactivate the Rathmore-Barraduff-Killarney project at a later date, they should resubmit it to the local NMS office. To date no request to reactivate the project has been received by the Manpower Service in Killarney.
